Your insurance approved treatment but denied payment afterward. Learn why this happens and how to appeal effectively under ERISA protections.

Insurance Claim Denied After Prior Approval: How to Appeal Post-Service Denials

Understanding Your Situation

You received prior authorization or pre-approval from your insurance company for a procedure, medication, or treatment. You followed all the rules, confirmed coverage, and proceeded with care. Then, weeks later, you receive a denial letter or Explanation of Benefits (EOB) stating the claim is denied. This situation — post-service denial after prior approval — is frustrating, confusing, and unfortunately common. Insurance companies sometimes approve care upfront but deny payment afterward, citing reasons like 'not medically necessary,' 'incorrect coding,' or 'failure to meet policy requirements.' While this practice seems contradictory, you have strong appeal rights, especially if you can prove prior authorization was granted.

Why This Happens

Post-service denials after approval occur because:

Prior Authorization Is Not a Payment Guarantee: Insurers often include disclaimers stating that prior authorization does not guarantee payment. They reserve the right to review claims again after service and deny based on final documentation.

Coding Discrepancies: Your provider may have submitted the claim with different CPT codes than what was approved in the prior authorization, triggering a denial.

Medical Necessity Disputes: The insurance company's post-service review may conclude the treatment was not medically necessary based on the actual medical records, even if pre-approved.

Policy Exclusions: The insurer may discover after the fact that your policy excludes the specific service or that you didn't meet all coverage criteria.

Plan Changes: If your insurance plan changed between pre-approval and service (e.g., employer changed carriers), coverage terms may have changed.

Administrative Errors: Mistakes in claim submission, missing documentation, or clerical errors can trigger denials even when prior authorization exists.

What To Check

Gather documentation to build your appeal:

✓ Locate your prior authorization letter or reference number — this is critical proof of approval
✓ Review the denial letter carefully — identify the specific reason code and denial explanation
✓ Compare the EOB to what was authorized — verify the CPT codes, dates, and services match
✓ Check your insurance policy — confirm the service is covered and you met all requirements
✓ Request the claim submission records from your provider — ensure they billed what was authorized
✓ Confirm your coverage was active — verify you had active coverage on the service date
✓ Review the prior authorization terms — check for conditions like timeframes or specific providers

What To Do Next

Step 1: File an Internal Appeal Immediately
Under ERISA, you typically have 180 days from the denial date to file an internal appeal. Do not wait. In your appeal:
• Reference your prior authorization number and approval date
• State clearly: 'Prior authorization was granted, constituting representation that the service was covered and medically necessary'
• Attach a copy of the prior authorization letter/approval
• Include your provider's medical records supporting medical necessity
• Cite your insurance policy's coverage language for the service

Step 2: Request Full Claim File
Under ERISA § 503, you have the right to request and receive the full claim file, including:
• All documents the insurer relied on to make the denial
• The specific policy provision or clinical guideline cited
• Any internal notes or reviewer comments

Use this information to identify weaknesses in the insurer's reasoning.

Step 3: Use Our Appeal Tool
Generate a professional, legally compliant appeal letter citing ERISA protections and prior authorization estoppel principles. Use our Insurance Claim Appeal tool.

Step 4: Request a Peer-to-Peer Review
If the denial is based on medical necessity, request that your treating physician speak directly with the insurer's medical director in a peer-to-peer review. Treating physicians often successfully overturn denials when explaining clinical rationale directly.

Step 5: Request External Review if Internal Appeal Fails
If your internal appeal is denied, you have the right to an independent external review at no cost. External reviewers overturn 40-50% of denials. File your external review request within the timeframe specified in your denial letter (usually 4-6 months).

For comprehensive guidance on insurance appeals, see our Insurance Claim Denials Hub.

Frequently Asked Questions

Doesn't prior authorization mean the claim is approved?

Not necessarily. Prior authorization confirms that the insurer agrees the service may be medically necessary and covered under your plan, but most insurers include disclaimers stating that final payment is subject to claim review. However, prior authorization creates a strong presumption of coverage, and denials after approval are often successfully appealed.

What if the provider billed different CPT codes than what was authorized?

This is a common cause of post-service denials. Contact your provider's billing department immediately and request they resubmit the claim with the CPT codes that were authorized. This is often a simple administrative fix that resolves the denial without a formal appeal.

Can I appeal even if I already paid the provider?

Yes. Paying your provider does not waive your right to appeal the insurance denial. If your appeal is successful, the insurer will reimburse you for the covered amount. Keep all payment receipts and include them in your appeal documentation.

How long does the appeal process take?

Internal appeals typically take 30 days for non-urgent claims and 72 hours for urgent claims. External reviews can take 30-60 days. If you're facing financial hardship, request an expedited review and explain why delay would cause serious harm.

What if my employer changed insurance plans between approval and service?

If your employer changed carriers and coverage terms changed, you may have a strong argument that you relied on the prior authorization in good faith. Consult an ERISA attorney, as these cases can be complex. Some courts have ruled in favor of patients who received prior approval under one plan even when the plan changed before service.
